DOC.HEAD: Leftist Bitterly Concedes Defeat in Presidential Race
DOC.TEXT: Socialist Luis Inacio Lula da Silva conceded defeat in the presidential election, but he accused conservative victor Fernando Collor de Mello of deception and pledged to build an opposition ``shadow government.'' Election officials announced Tuesday that Collor de Mello, a champion of free-market policies, had won Sunday's balloting. ``Fernando Collor de Mello is the winner and that must be respected. But Brazil was the big loser in the election, gained through lies and falsehoods,'' da Silva told a news conference in Sao Paulo. ``He will govern in favor of big business, the armed forces, and the International Monetary Fund,'' de Silva said. ``The Workers Party and its allies will form a shadow government to prevent Collor de Mello from committing abuses.'' With 96.7 percent of the ballots tallied, Collor de Mello of the National Reconstruction Party had 33,898,190 votes, or 42.7 percent, compared with 30,546,337, or 38.5 percent, for da Silva of the Workers Party. The rest of the votes were abstentions or nullified ballots. Jose Francisco Rezek, president of the Superior Electoral Court that was supervising the tally, said Collor de Mello would be declared the winner Wednesday, but an official announcement would only be made Dec. 29. The election was the first direct vote for president in 29 years. Current president Jose Sarney was selected in an Electoral College vote strongly influenced by the right-wing military government that ran the country between 1964 and 1985. Collor de Mello has been secluded in his Brasilia mansion. Aides say he will only address the nation after election officials proclaim him the winner. TV Globo, the nation's largest television network, ran a previously taped interview with the president-elect Tuesday night in which Collor de Mello promised a government with ``dignity, austerity and character.'' The new president's first challenge will be harnassing inflation racing at over 1,500 percent this year amid growing poverty. Collor de Mello's campaign advisers have told the press he will seek to heal the wounds from the electoral campaign and call for a government of ``national unity.'' However, the wounds run deep. In the campaign's final week, Collor de Mello's campaign made vicious personal attacks on da Silva and said his party wanted to impose a communist dictatorship in Brazil. ``I would never sit at the same table with Collor de Mello. The low blows he used caused me to lose all respect for him,'' da Silva said at the Tuesday press conference. He said Collor de Mello, scheduled to take office on March 15, will face strong opposition from labor unions and six leftist parties. During the electoral campaign, Collor de Mello promised to end inflation, privatize state-run firms, reduce the size of government, and sell Cabinet minister's mansions to reduce the public deficit. He also won the vote of a great part of the uneducated rural poor by pledging to increase spending for housing, education and health care. To realize these promises, Collor de Mello must seek allies in the country's National Congress. The new president's party has 24 senators and representatives, only 3 percent of those in congress. Da Silva said his party would back Collor de Mello if he sincerely attempted to carry out social reforms in this polarized society, where the richest 1 percent receives almost half the national income. ``But I'm afraid his call for national unity is nothing more than a trick to keep the working class quiet,'' he said.
